trial_identification.studytitle: Lid Wiper Epitheliopathy: Exploring the links with osmolality and ocular comfort during contact lens wear
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A prospective, randomised, double-masked, controlled, cross-over study of the effects of wearing lotrafilcon A versus comfilcom A silicone hydrogel lenses for up to 10 days on lid wiper epitheliopathy in healthy lens wearing participants.

interventions.interventions: Participants will be randomised to wear either lotrafilcon A silicone hydrogel contact lenses on a daily wear basis for up to 10 days OR comfilcon A silicone hydrogel contact lenses on a daily wear basis flor up to 10 days and then, following a washout period of 7 days where no lenses are worn, crossed over to the other lens group. Hydrogen peroxide disinfection system (AOSept or Omnicare) will be used for disinfection after each day of wear.
interventions.comparator: No lens wear during wash out periods of 7 days duration before interventions. The effect of the two interventions will be compared to each other and to the no lens wear condition following the 1 week washout period.

primaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline and after up to 10 days after intervention commencement

secondaryOutcome.outcome: contact lens osmolality (mmol/kg) measured using a vapour pressure osmometer
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: after up to 10 days after intervention commencement
baseline and after up to 10 days after intervention commencement

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Ability to wear contact lenses, no contraindications to lens wear, no lens wear in the past 7 days
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Required use of any ocular eye drops other than unit dose saline rewetting drops during the study period

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: School of Optometry and Vision Science
sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: c/o Dr Isabelle Jalbert School of Optometry and Vision Science The University of New South Wales Entry via Gate 14, Barker Street Rupert Myers Building (North Wing) Kensington NSW 2033

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This project aims to deepen our understanding of the causes of discomfort during contact lens wear. Participants will wear two types of contact lenses (lotrafilcon and comfilcon) for up to 10 days at a time.The project hypothesises that there is a link between the saltiness of peoples' tears, of their contact lenses and the presence of superficial damage to the portion of the upper eyelid that wipes over the contact lens and the sensation of discomfort during lens wear.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: 1. Stahl U, Delaveris A, Madigan M, Jalbert I. Lid wiper epitheliopathy: exploring the links to comfort and osmolality in contact lens wear. British Contact Lens Association Annual Clinical Conference (BCLA) 2011, Manchester, UK, 2011. 2. Delaveris N, Stahl UG, Madigan M, Jalbert I. Do lissamine green strips from various manufacturers perform equally? Clin Exp Optom 2011;94: 613-614.
